items.standfirst: Steve Witkoff says Russian president agreed to allow US and European allies to offer Ukraine security guarantee and also unspecified concessions on five Ukrainian regionsGermany’s chancellor, Friedrich Merz, will also be travelling to Washington tomorrow for the Trump-Zelenskyy talks, according to the federal government.The chancellor’s spokesperson has been quoted by BBC News as having said:The trip will serve as an exchange of information with US President Donald Trump following his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Alaska.Chancellor Merz will discuss the status of peace efforts with the heads of state and government and underscore Germany’s interest in a swift peace agreement in Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.title: WEEKLY PREVIEW: All eyes still on Alaska summit
items.standfirst: Just like the previous week, the next seven days will also be marked by the summit between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin, the respective presidents of the United States and Russia, which took place ...

items.title: NATO-like protection for Ukraine in focus as Zelensky, European leaders head for Trump meeting
items.standfirst: European and NATO leaders are joining Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Washington on Monday to present a united front in talks with President Donald Trump as US special envoy Steve Witkoff on Sunday said Russia is open to the idea of the US and its European allies offering Ukraine a security guarantee resembling NATO’s collective defence mandate.
items.content: European and NATO leaders are joining Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Washington on Monday to present a united front in talks with President Donald Trump as US special envoy Steve Witkoff on Sunday said Russia is open to the idea of the US and its European allies offering Ukraine a security guarantee resembling NATO’s collective defence mandate.

items.title: These European leaders will accompany Zelensky to meet with Trump

items.title: UK and EU at Zelenskyy’s side in Washington for meeting with Trump
items.standfirst: Emmanuel Macron, Friedrich Merz and others will aim to push back against ceding of Ukraine territory in ‘peace plan’European leaders including Keir Starmer will join Volodymyr Zelenskyy at a White House meeting with Donald Trump on Monday in an extraordinary joint effort to push back on a US-backed plan that would allow Russia to take further Ukrainian territory.As well as the UK prime minister, the French president, Emmanuel Macron, Germany’s chancellor, Friedrich Merz, Italy’s PM, Giorgia Meloni, and the Finnish president, Alexander Stubb, will all accompany Zelenskyy in the Oval Office. Continue reading...
items.content: Emmanuel Macron, Friedrich Merz and others will aim to push back against ceding of Ukraine territory in ‘peace plan’European leaders including Keir Starmer will join Volodymyr Zelenskyy at a White House meeting with Donald Trump on Monday in an extraordinary joint effort to push back on a US-backed plan that would allow Russia to take further Ukrainian territory.As well as the UK prime minister, the French president, Emmanuel Macron, Germany’s chancellor, Friedrich Merz, Italy’s PM, Giorgia Meloni, and the Finnish president, Alexander Stubb, will all accompany Zelenskyy in the Oval Office. Continue reading...

items.title: After meeting Putin, Trump changes his position on the need for a ceasefire
items.standfirst: When President Trump was flying to Alaska to meet Vladimir Putin, he said the goal was a ceasefire. But after they talked, Trump aligned himself with Putin and downplayed the need for a truce.
items.content: When President Trump was flying to Alaska to meet Vladimir Putin, he said the goal was a ceasefire. But after they talked, Trump aligned himself with Putin and downplayed the need for a truce. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

items.title: Putin agreed to allow NATO-style protection for Ukraine, Trump envoy says
items.standfirst: Special U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff says Russian leader Vladimir Putin agreed to allow the U.S. and Europe to offer Ukraine a security guarantee resembling NATO's collective defense mandate.
items.content: Special U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff says Russian leader Vladimir Putin agreed to allow the U.S. and Europe to offer Ukraine a security guarantee resembling NATO's collective defense mandate.

items.title: Keir Starmer hopes to exploit curious relationship with Trump in Ukraine talks
items.standfirst: PM has positioned himself as someone who can get along with US president while stressing Europe’s red linesAsked behind the scenes at June’s G7 summit if he could explain why Donald Trump seemed to like him so much, Keir Starmer admitted he did not really know. Whatever the reason, when it comes to Ukraine, the UK prime minister is once again hoping to exploit this somewhat curious relationship.As soon as it was announced that a string of European leaders planned to join Volodymyr Zelenskyy to back the Ukrainian president in crucial talks with Trump at the White House on Monday, it was obvious Starmer would be joining them. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin has agreed Ukraine can have 'NATO-style' security guarantee, US envoy says
items.standfirst: Vladimir Putin has agreed to allow Ukraine's allies to offer it a NATO-like security guarantee as part of an eventual deal to end the war, according to US special envoy Steve Witkoff.
items.content: Vladimir Putin has agreed to allow Ukraine's allies to offer it a NATO-like security guarantee as part of an eventual deal to end the war, according to US special envoy Steve Witkoff.

items.title: Trump drops ceasefire demand, echoing Putin’s position and jittering Ukraine
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump reversed course after his meeting in Alaska with Russia’s Vladimir Putin by abandoning his demand for a ceasefire and adopting a Kremlin position calling for a full peace deal to end the Ukraine war.
items.content: US President Donald Trump reversed course after his meeting in Alaska with Russia’s Vladimir Putin by abandoning his demand for a ceasefire and adopting a Kremlin position calling for a full peace deal to end the Ukraine war.

items.title: European leaders to join Zelenskyy in Washington after Trump's shift toward Putin
items.standfirst: Ukraine and its allies were scrambling Sunday to respond to President Donald Trump's apparent shift toward Vladimir Putin's hardline position after their summit in Alaska.
items.content: Ukraine and its allies were scrambling Sunday to respond to President Donald Trump's apparent shift toward Vladimir Putin's hardline position after their summit in Alaska.

items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin addressed senior officials in the Kremlin on the outcome of talks with President Donald Trump in Alaska.

items.title: War rages on in Ukraine as Trump and Putin meet but don’t announce deal

items.content: NBC News’ Richard Engel reports from the frontlines in Ukraine as the summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin ends without a ceasefire.

items.title: How the Trump-Putin summit unfolded... in under 2 minutes
items.standfirst: The meeting concluded with no deal being reached between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin but "great progress" was made in Ukraine talks.
items.content: The meeting concluded with no deal being reached between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin but "great progress" was made in Ukraine talks.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Trump and Putin discussed Ukraine security guarantees, according to a US envoy.
• Zelenskyy stated territorial swaps are not possible under the Ukrainian constitution.
• German Chancellor Merz will meet with Trump to discuss peace efforts in Ukraine.
• European leaders will join Zelenskyy in Washington for talks with Trump.
• The Monday discussion could prove challenging for all parties involved.

items.content: The strike, which began on Saturday morning, stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during the peak summer travel season.

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants defy back-to-work order, continue strike
items.standfirst: The union representing Air Canada's striking flight attendants on Sunday said it will remain on strike and spurn a government return-to-work order that they called unconstitutional. The strike has stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer travel season.
items.content: The union representing Air Canada's striking flight attendants on Sunday said it will remain on strike and spurn a government return-to-work order that they called unconstitutional. The strike has stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer travel season.

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants to defy back-to-work order and remain on strike
items.standfirst: Union to challenge order issued less than 12 hours after start of action that has left more than 100,000 travellers strandedAir Canada’s flight attendants plan to remain on strike, their union has said, defying government efforts to force them back to work and into binding arbitration over a dispute that has left more than 100,000 travellers stranded around the world during the peak summer travel season.About 10,000 flight attendants who work for Canada’s largest airline walked out on the job early on Saturday amid a bitter dispute over what the union has described as “poverty wages” and unpaid labour. Continue reading...
items.content: Union to challenge order issued less than 12 hours after start of action that has left more than 100,000 travellers strandedAir Canada’s flight attendants plan to remain on strike, their union has said, defying government efforts to force them back to work and into binding arbitration over a dispute that has left more than 100,000 travellers stranded around the world during the peak summer travel season.About 10,000 flight attendants who work for Canada’s largest airline walked out on the job early on Saturday amid a bitter dispute over what the union has described as “poverty wages” and unpaid labour. Continue reading...

items.title: Air Canada halts flight restart after union defies back-to-work order
items.standfirst: Air Canada said Sunday it has suspended its plan to resume limited flights after the union representing its flight attendants told members to defy a federal order to return to work.
items.content: Air Canada said Sunday it has suspended its plan to resume limited flights after the union representing its flight attendants told members to defy a federal order to return to work.

items.title: Air Canada to resume flights after government ends flight attendant strike
items.standfirst: Canada’s labour board has ordered Air Canada to resume operations after a nationwide flight attendant strike grounded over 700 flights. The directive, issued following a request from Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu, marks the end of the airline’s first flight attendant walkout since 1985.
items.content: Canada’s labour board has ordered Air Canada to resume operations after a nationwide flight attendant strike grounded over 700 flights. The directive, issued following a request from Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu, marks the end of the airline’s first flight attendant walkout since 1985.

items.title: Three Republican-led states to send hundreds of National Guard troops to Washington
items.standfirst: West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 Guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio says it will send 150 in the coming days, marking a significant escalation of the federal intervention.
items.content: West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 Guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio says it will send 150 in the coming days, marking a significant escalation of the federal intervention.(Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

items.title: Three states to deploy hundreds of national guard troops to Washington DC
items.standfirst: South Carolina and Ohio join West Virginia in pledging troops, fueling protests that national guard should not be used for ‘a political policing mission’Three states have moved to deploy hundreds of members of their national guard to the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in Washington through a federal crackdown. West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days.The moves announced on Saturday came as protesters pushed back on federal law enforcement and national guard troops fanning out in the heavily Democratic city following Donald Trump’s executive order federalizing local police forces and activating about 800 District of Columbia national guard members. Continue reading...
items.content: South Carolina and Ohio join West Virginia in pledging troops, fueling protests that national guard should not be used for ‘a political policing mission’Three states have moved to deploy hundreds of members of their national guard to the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in Washington through a federal crackdown. West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days.The moves announced on Saturday came as protesters pushed back on federal law enforcement and national guard troops fanning out in the heavily Democratic city following Donald Trump’s executive order federalizing local police forces and activating about 800 District of Columbia national guard members. Continue reading...

items.title: Canadian government orders arbitration to resolve Air Canada flight attendants' strike
items.standfirst: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in.
items.content: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in.

clusters.ai_summary:
• National Guard troops are deploying to Washington, D.C. from multiple states.
• Air Canada flight attendants defied a return-to-work order from the government.
• The strike forced Air Canada to delay plans to resume flights on Sunday.
• The strike affected approximately 130,000 travelers daily during peak season.
• Air Canada suspended restart plans after the union's defiance of the order.

clusters.title: Tens of thousands of protesters gather in Tel Aviv to demand end to Gaza war
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests in Israel Demand End to Gaza War, Hostage Release
bullet_summary: Meanwhile, Israel said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza
"It may be part of a psychological warfare operation to try and persuade Gazans to leave their homes or whatever spaces they were in, in central Gaza", she said

items.title: Tens of thousands of protesters gather in Tel Aviv to demand end to Gaza war
items.standfirst: One of largest rallies in Israel since start of conflict follows general strike to press government to stop military actionTens of thousands of demonstrators have gathered in Tel Aviv to call for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.The rally on Sunday evening was the culmination of a day of nationwide protests and a general strike to pressure the government to halt the military campaign. “Bring them all home! Stop the war!” shouted the vast crowd, which had converged on the so-called Hostage Square in Tel Aviv plaza – a focal point for protesters throughout the war. Continue reading...
items.content: One of largest rallies in Israel since start of conflict follows general strike to press government to stop military actionTens of thousands of demonstrators have gathered in Tel Aviv to call for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.The rally on Sunday evening was the culmination of a day of nationwide protests and a general strike to pressure the government to halt the military campaign. “Bring them all home! Stop the war!” shouted the vast crowd, which had converged on the so-called Hostage Square in Tel Aviv plaza – a focal point for protesters throughout the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Huge crowds gather in Israel calling for hostage deal and end to Gaza war
items.standfirst: Large crowds fill 'Hostages Square' in Tel Aviv to call for fighting to cease and the release of all remaining hostages by Hamas.
items.content: Large crowds fill 'Hostages Square' in Tel Aviv to call for fighting to cease and the release of all remaining hostages by Hamas.

items.title: Mass rallies erupt across Israel as protesters demand end to Gaza war, hostage deal
items.standfirst: Mass protests erupted across Israel Sunday as tens of thousands called for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.
items.content: Mass protests erupted across Israel Sunday as tens of thousands called for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.

items.title: Israeli plan to displace 1 million Palestinians spreads fear in Gaza
items.standfirst: Population devastated by repeated displacement, hunger and lack of medical supplies braces for further humanitarian disaster Palestinians were gripped by fear and anxiety on Sunday after the Israeli military said it was preparing for the forcible displacement of 1 million people from Gaza City.The announcement came days after Israel said it intended to launch a new offensive to seize control of the territory’s largest urban centre, in a plan that raised international alarm, and ahead of the IDF’s latest attacks in the Palestinian territory which Gaza’s health officials said had killed at least 40 people on Saturday including a baby in a tent and people seeking aid. Continue reading...
items.content: Population devastated by repeated displacement, hunger and lack of medical supplies braces for further humanitarian disaster Palestinians were gripped by fear and anxiety on Sunday after the Israeli military said it was preparing for the forcible displacement of 1 million people from Gaza City.The announcement came days after Israel said it intended to launch a new offensive to seize control of the territory’s largest urban centre, in a plan that raised international alarm, and ahead of the IDF’s latest attacks in the Palestinian territory which Gaza’s health officials said had killed at least 40 people on Saturday including a baby in a tent and people seeking aid. Continue reading...

items.title: Protesters go on strike in Israel demanding ceasefire
items.standfirst: Protestors in Israel demanding their government make a deal to secure the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza escalated their campaign on Sunday, (August 16) staging a strike. Meanwhile, Israel said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky tells us more. "It may be part of a psychological warfare operation to try and persuade Gazans to leave their homes or whatever spaces they were in, in central Gaza", she said.
items.content: Protestors in Israel demanding their government make a deal to secure the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza escalated their campaign on Sunday, (August 16) staging a strike. Meanwhile, Israel said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky tells us more. "It may be part of a psychological warfare operation to try and persuade Gazans to leave their homes or whatever spaces they were in, in central Gaza", she said.

items.title: Israeli military prepares to move Palestinians to southern Gaza
items.standfirst: International condemnation and pressure from allies have done nothing to stop Israel's plan to displace the people of northern Gaza. Israel on Saturday (August 16) said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas
items.content: International condemnation and pressure from allies have done nothing to stop Israel's plan to displace the people of northern Gaza. Israel on Saturday (August 16) said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas

items.title: Nationwide protests over Gaza war, hostage deal sweep Israel
items.standfirst: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday (August 17), demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages, as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory. Protest organisers and the main campaign group representing the families of hostages also called for a general strike.
items.content: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday (August 17), demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages, as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory. Protest organisers and the main campaign group representing the families of hostages also called for a general strike.

items.title: Protesters go on strike in Israel demanding ceasefire and release of Gaza hostages
items.standfirst: More than 30 people have been arrested in Israel for "disruption of order" as families of hostages held in Gaza step up their campaign with a nationwide strike.
items.content: More than 30 people have been arrested in Israel for "disruption of order" as families of hostages held in Gaza step up their campaign with a nationwide strike.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Tens of thousands protested in Tel Aviv, calling for an end to the war.
• The demonstration was one of the largest since the conflict began in October 2023.
• Protesters demanded the release of hostages held by Hamas.
• A general strike preceded the rally, pressuring the government.
• The Israeli military is preparing for the displacement of 1 million Palestinians.

clusters.title: Bolivians go to polls in election that could end 20 years of leftist rule

bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, Al Jazeera, France24

items.title: Bolivians go to polls in election that could end 20 years of leftist rule
items.standfirst: Rightwing candidates lead polling ahead of fragmented left amid country’s worst economic crisis in four decadesBolivians are going to the polls in an election that could mark a shift to the right and the end of nearly 20 years of rule by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The party, which came to power with the first election of Evo Morales in 2005, risks losing its legal status if it fails to reach 3% of the vote – a threshold it has not hit in polls. Continue reading...
items.content: Rightwing candidates lead polling ahead of fragmented left amid country’s worst economic crisis in four decadesBolivians are going to the polls in an election that could mark a shift to the right and the end of nearly 20 years of rule by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The party, which came to power with the first election of Evo Morales in 2005, risks losing its legal status if it fails to reach 3% of the vote – a threshold it has not hit in polls. Continue reading...

items.content: Bolivians head to the polls Sunday (August 17) for elections marked by a deep economic crisis that has seen the left implode and the right eyeing its first shot at power in 20 years.

clusters.ai_summary:

items.content: Tesco, Asda and Sainsbury’s said they had ‘immediately’ suspended supplies from Somerby Top Farm after piglets kicked by workers Three of the UK’s biggest supermarkets have suspended supplies from a Lincolnshire pig farm after footage filmed covertly by an animal rights organisation appeared to…

items.title: Supermarkets suspend supplies from Lincolnshire pig farm over animal abuse footage
items.standfirst: Tesco, Asda and Sainsbury’s said they had ‘immediately’ suspended supplies from Somerby Top Farm after piglets kicked by workersThree of the UK’s biggest supermarkets have suspended supplies from a Lincolnshire pig farm after footage filmed covertly by an animal rights organisation appeared to show workers kicking piglets and hitting them with boards and paddles.The footage also suggested the injured pigs with open wounds were packed into pens covered in faeces, with some left lame and writhing in pain. Continue reading...
items.content: Tesco, Asda and Sainsbury’s said they had ‘immediately’ suspended supplies from Somerby Top Farm after piglets kicked by workersThree of the UK’s biggest supermarkets have suspended supplies from a Lincolnshire pig farm after footage filmed covertly by an animal rights organisation appeared to show workers kicking piglets and hitting them with boards and paddles.The footage also suggested the injured pigs with open wounds were packed into pens covered in faeces, with some left lame and writhing in pain. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Supermarkets suspended supplies from a Lincolnshire pig farm.
• Footage showed workers kicking and hitting piglets.
• The footage was filmed covertly by an animal rights organization.
• Injured pigs were packed into pens with open wounds.
• Tesco, Asda, and Sainsbury's took immediate action.

clusters.title: Rubio says "both sides are going to have to make concessions" to end Ukraine war
clusters.neutral_headline: Rubio Says Both Sides Must Make Concessions for Ukraine Peace
bullet_summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said "both sides are going to have to make concessions" to end Russia's war in Ukraine
“You can’t have a peace agreement unless both sides make concessions – that’s a fact,” the Trump administration’s top diplomat said Sunday on ABC’s This Week

items.title: Rubio says "both sides are going to have to make concessions" to end Ukraine war
items.standfirst: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said "both sides are going to have to make concessions" to end Russia's war in Ukraine.
items.content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said "both sides are going to have to make concessions" to end Russia's war in Ukraine.

items.title: Rubio says both Russia and Ukraine ‘have to make concessions’ for peace deal
items.standfirst: US secretary of state says talks between Putin and Trump had ‘made progress’ but ‘big areas of disagreement’ remainIn a combative series of interviews on Sunday, the US secretary of state, Marco Rubio, said that “both sides are going to have to make concessions” for there to be a peaceful resolution to the war that erupted when Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022.“You can’t have a peace agreement unless both sides make concessions – that’s a fact,” the Trump administration’s top diplomat said Sunday on ABC’s This Week. “That’s true in virtually any negotiation. If not, it’s just called surrender. And neither side is going to surrender. So both sides are going to have to make concessions.” Continue reading...
items.content: US secretary of state says talks between Putin and Trump had ‘made progress’ but ‘big areas of disagreement’ remainIn a combative series of interviews on Sunday, the US secretary of state, Marco Rubio, said that “both sides are going to have to make concessions” for there to be a peaceful resolution to the war that erupted when Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022.“You can’t have a peace agreement unless both sides make concessions – that’s a fact,” the Trump administration’s top diplomat said Sunday on ABC’s This Week. “That’s true in virtually any negotiation. If not, it’s just called surrender. And neither side is going to surrender. So both sides are going to have to make concessions.” Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Marco Rubio stated both sides must make concessions for peace.
• He said this in interviews on Sunday.
• Rubio stated that talks between Putin and Trump made progress.
• He noted that big areas of disagreement remain.
• Rubio said that surrender is not an option for either side.

items.title: Hurricane Erin weakens to category 3 as storm lashes Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands
items.standfirst: First Atlantic hurricane of 2025 diminishes but tropical storm warnings issued for Turks and CaicosHurricane Erin was downgraded to a category 3 hurricane early Sunday as its outer bands continued to lash the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico with heavy rains and tropical-storm force winds.While Erin’s maximum winds diminished, the storm’s overall size grew and forecasters issued tropical storm warnings for the Turks and Caicos Islands and a watch for the south-east Bahamas. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Death toll after monsoon floods in Pakistan rises to more than 320
items.standfirst: Most of the dead were reported in the mountainous province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, with more rain forecastThe death toll from heavy monsoon rains that have triggered flash floods across northern Pakistan has risen to at least 321 people in the past 48 hours, the country’s disaster authority said on Saturday.The majority of the deaths, 307, were recorded in the mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, according to the National Disaster Management Authority. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.content: Hundreds are reported missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province as a result of devastating floods.

items.title: Pakistan expands rescue and relief efforts after flash floods
items.standfirst: At least 150 people are missing in northwest Pakistan, the head of the provincial disaster authority said Sunday (August 17), after flash floods that have killed at least 344 people in the country. Thousands of rescuers were battling rain and knee-deep mud, digging homes out from under massive boulders in a desperate search for survivors.
items.content: At least 150 people are missing in northwest Pakistan, the head of the provincial disaster authority said Sunday (August 17), after flash floods that have killed at least 344 people in the country. Thousands of rescuers were battling rain and knee-deep mud, digging homes out from under massive boulders in a desperate search for survivors.

items.title: At least 150 still missing in Pakistan after deadly flash floods
items.standfirst: At least 150 people are missing in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province following devastating flash floods that have killed at least 344 nationwide, officials said Sunday. Rescue efforts are underway, with fears that many victims may be trapped under rubble or swept away by raging waters.
items.content: At least 150 people are missing in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province following devastating flash floods that have killed at least 344 nationwide, officials said Sunday. Rescue efforts are underway, with fears that many victims may be trapped under rubble or swept away by raging waters.

• Thousands of rescuers are battling rain and mud.
• Many victims may be trapped under rubble or swept away.

clusters.title: Tensions soar in Serbia as protesters clash with police, set fire to party offices
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests Erupt in Serbia Following Railway Station Collapse
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, NBC World

items.title: Tensions soar in Serbia as protesters clash with police, set fire to party offices
items.standfirst: Fresh clashes erupted late Saturday (august 17) between protesters and riot police in Serbia's capital Belgrade and other cities, on the fifth consecutive night of unrest. Almost daily protests have gripped Serbia since November, following the collapse of a railway station roof that killed 16 people. The tragedy became a symbol of deep-rooted corruption in the Balkan nation, with demands for a transparent investigation growing into calls for early elections.
items.content: Fresh clashes erupted late Saturday (august 17) between protesters and riot police in Serbia's capital Belgrade and other cities, on the fifth consecutive night of unrest. Almost daily protests have gripped Serbia since November, following the collapse of a railway station roof that killed 16 people. The tragedy became a symbol of deep-rooted corruption in the Balkan nation, with demands for a transparent investigation growing into calls for early elections.

items.title: Serbian police use tear gas against protesters in Belgrade
items.standfirst: Serbian police officers threw tear gas and charged against protesters as tensions escalated between authorities and anti-government protesters in the capital. The country has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.
items.content: Serbian police officers threw tear gas and charged against protesters as tensions escalated between authorities and anti-government protesters in the capital. The country has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Protests and clashes with police occurred in Belgrade and other Serbian cities.
• The protests have continued for five consecutive nights.
• The protests began after a railway station roof collapse killed sixteen people.
• The tragedy is seen as a symbol of corruption in Serbia.
• Protesters are demanding a transparent investigation and early elections.
